trial_identification.studytitle: The feasibility of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) treatment for sleep disordered breathing in acute tetraplegia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The feasibility of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) treatment for sleep disordered breathing in acute tetraplegia

conditions.healthcondition: Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA) in acute tetraplegia

interventions.interventions: Three months trial of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) treatment for OSA in tetraplegia

primaryOutcome.outcome: Effectiveness of change in oxygen desaturation rate
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measurements of effectiveness will be made at baseline and after 3 months
Adherence will be monitored daily and recorded weekly

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The amount and nature of the assistance required to maximise CPAP uptake will be examined to determine what proportion of subjects required what amount of support.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: These measures will be made daily and recorded weekly.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Acute tetraplegia. All American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) classifications and lesion levels will be included.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Admission, physician diagnosis of significant head injury, significant pre-existing respiratory or cardiac disease and any other significant co-morbidity. An inability of provide informed consent. Planned hospital discharge within six weeks.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study is designed to examine the feasibility of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) treatment for Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA) in acute tetraplegia. This pilot study will examine how well CPAP is tolerated and if treatment is feasible prior to the commencement of any randomised, controlled trial of therapy.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Berlowitz DJ, Spong J, Pierce RJ, Ross J, Barnes M & Brown DJ. The feasibility of using auto-titrating continuous positive airway pressure to treat obstructive sleep apnoea after acute tetraplegia. Spinal Cord 2009 47: 868-873.
